description: From Latin congregatus, past participle of congregare (“to congregate”), from con- (“with, together”) + gregare (“to collect into a flock”), from grex (“flock, herd”). See gregarious.

adjectives.description: congregate (comparative more congregate, superlative most congregate)

examples: With this reservation, therefore, we proceed to human philosophy or humanity, which hath two parts: the one considereth man segregate or distributively, the other congregate or in society; so as human philosophy is either simple and particular, or conjugate and civil.

verbs.description: congregate (third-person singular simple present congregates, present participle congregating, simple past and past participle congregated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To collect into an assembly or assemblage; to bring into one place, or into a united body.
examples: Synonyms: amass, assemble, compact, bring together, gather, mass; see also Thesaurus:round up

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To come together; to assemble; to meet.
examples: Synonyms: assemble, begather, forgather; see also Thesaurus:assemble
